name: Public Procurement Act
description: Key provisions of the Public Procurement Act 2007, covering objectives, procedures, methods, thresholds, and penalties.

subcategories.name: Objectives and Institutions
subcategories.description: Objectives of the PPA, establishment of BPP, procurement planning committee, and procurement units

questions.question: In which year was the Public Procurement Act enacted in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Public Procurement Act was enacted in 2007 to regulate public procurement practices in Nigeria [1], [2].

questions.question: Which body is established by the Public Procurement Act to oversee procurement in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Bureau of Public Procurement (BPP) is established under the Act as the regulatory authority for procurement [3], [4].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 establishes the Bureau of Public Procurement?
questions.explanation: Section 3 of the PPA 2007 legally establishes the Bureau of Public Procurement (BPP) [5], [6].

questions.question: Which of the following is **NOT** an objective of the Public Procurement Act?
questions.explanation: The Act seeks to promote transparency, competition, efficiency, and value for money, explicitly prohibiting corruption [7], [8].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to issue guidelines and regulations to MDAs?
questions.explanation: Section 5 gives BPP the power to issue guidelines, manuals, and regulations for standardized procurement [9], [10].

questions.question: Which section requires all procuring entities to establish a Procurement Planning Committee (PPC)?
questions.explanation: Section 21 requires every procuring entity to have a Procurement Planning Committee [9], [11], [12].

questions.question: Who statutorily chairs the Procurement Planning Committee of a Ministry?
questions.explanation: The Procurement Planning Committee is chaired by the Permanent Secretary or Chief Executive Officer (the Accounting Officer) of the procuring entity [13], [11].

questions.question: What is the primary operational role of the Procurement Unit in an MDA?
options: Prepare bidding documents and manage procurement processes
questions.explanation: Procurement Units prepare bidding documents, manage the process flow, and support the Procurement Planning Committee [14].

questions.question: Which section provides for the establishment of procurement journals to publish notices?
questions.explanation: Section 12 mandates the publication of procurement journals to ensure wide dissemination of information [15].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to maintain and update a national database of contractors and service providers?
questions.explanation: Sections 5 and 9 empower the BPP to maintain and update a national database of eligible contractors [16].

questions.question: The power to organize and carry out training for procurement officers falls under which BPP power?
questions.explanation: Section 5 empowers the BPP to organize training and build capacity of procurement officers [17].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to issue Certificates of 'No Objection' to contract awards above designated thresholds?
questions.explanation: Section 5 mandates BPP to issue a 'Certificate of No Objection' before high-value contract awards can be finalized [18], [19].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to inspect procurement records and documents of entities to ensure compliance?
questions.explanation: Section 5 empowers the BPP to inspect procurement records to ensure compliance [19].

questions.question: Which section covers the conduct of mandatory procurement audits by the BPP?
questions.explanation: Section 6 empowers BPP to conduct procurement audits of procuring entities [20].

questions.question: The primary objective of the Public Procurement Act, 2007 is to ensure:
options: Transparency, accountability, and value for money
questions.explanation: The Act's goal is to ensure transparency, accountability, and value for money in public expenditure [21], [8].

questions.question: Which section prohibits a procuring entity from initiating procurement without approved budgetary provision and availability of funds?
questions.explanation: Section 14 strictly prohibits procurement without approved budgetary provision [22], [23], [24].

questions.question: The principle that mandates MDAs to seek the best combination of cost and quality/specifications is known as:
questions.explanation: Section 16 emphasizes that all procurement must achieve optimum value for money [25].

questions.question: The Act prohibits the illegal breaking down of a contract to circumvent approval thresholds, a practice known as:
questions.explanation: Section 16 (and Section 58(4)) explicitly prohibits the splitting of contracts to evade approval thresholds [26], [27].

questions.question: Which procurement method is designated as the default and preferred approach to ensure fair competition?
questions.explanation: Open Competitive Bidding is the mandatory default procurement method under Section 24 of the PPA 2007 [28], [29], [30].

questions.question: When is **Direct Procurement (Sole Sourcing)** generally permitted under the PPA?
options: When the Accounting Officer prefers a specific vendor.
Only in cases of extreme urgency (emergency) or single source availability.
For any contract below â‚¦5 million.
questions.explanation: Direct Procurement (Section 42) is permitted only for emergencies or proprietary purchases where only one known source exists [31], [32], [33].

questions.question: The use of **Restricted Tendering** (Selective Tendering) requires prior approval and is justified when:
options: Goods or services are available only from a limited number of qualified suppliers.
The MDA wants to prioritize local content.
questions.explanation: Restricted Tendering (Section 40) is used when few known suppliers exist, necessitating justification and approval [34], [35].

questions.question: The principle of **Due Process** in public procurement mandates:
options: Contract award to the cheapest bidder regardless of quality.
Strict adherence to all legal and procedural requirements of the PPA.
The inclusion of a military representative in the Tenders Board.
Exclusive use of Sole Sourcing methods.
questions.explanation: Due Process emphasizes strict compliance with legal, procedural, and administrative requirements throughout the contract process [36], [37].

questions.question: Procurement involving supplies, materials, equipment, and tangible supplies falls under which PPA classification?
questions.explanation: The PPA classifies procurement into Goods (tangible supplies), Works (construction), and Services (advisory/operational) [38].

questions.question: Procurement covering the construction, rehabilitation, or physical improvement of infrastructure falls under which PPA classification?
questions.explanation: Works are classified as infrastructure projects (construction, rehabilitation, or improvement of physical assets) [38].

questions.question: The acquisition of specialized intellectual or advisory tasks (e.g., strategic consulting) is classified under:
questions.explanation: Consultancy Services involve intellectual or advisory tasks and require specific selection methods (Section 43) [38].

questions.question: Who is ultimately responsible for ensuring all financial commitments, including procurement, comply with the PPA and budgetary limits within an MDA?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/CEO, as the Chief Accounting Officer, holds ultimate personal responsibility for expenditure control and compliance [39], [40], [41].

questions.question: Before an MDA commences procurement planning, the PPC must establish the justification and scope through a:
questions.explanation: Needs Assessment precedes planning (Section 21) and determines the project scope, technical specifications, and quantities required, ensuring alignment with the budget [12].

questions.question: Procurement documents and records must be retained for audit and inspection purposes for a minimum period of:
questions.explanation: Procurement documents must be retained for at least 5 years (Section 38) to support potential audits and inquiries [42], [43], [44].

questions.question: The use of **International Competitive Bidding (ICB)** is sanctioned under which Section of the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 27 provides for International Competitive Bidding when national competitive bidding is inadequate or the required goods/services are unavailable locally [45], [46].

questions.question: Which body is responsible for setting and publishing the actual monetary threshold limits (e.g., â‚¦50m, â‚¦100m) for MDAs' internal approval boards?
questions.explanation: The BPP establishes and publishes the Threshold Manual, setting approval limits for Accounting Officers and Tender Boards [47], [48].

questions.question: The rule that allows for preferential scoring or price advantage for local firms to encourage the use of Nigerian goods and services is known as:
questions.explanation: Section 35 allows for Domestic Preference in procurement to support local industry [49].

questions.question: Procurement undertaken to address unexpected events like disasters or national security threats, where rapid action is mandatory, is called:
questions.explanation: Emergency Procurement (Section 42) is reserved for unforeseen events where competitive delays would compromise life or security [31], [33].

questions.question: What is the mandatory administrative action required immediately after concluding an Emergency Procurement (Section 42)?
options: Publicizing the award in the National Gazette.
Submitting a detailed report detailing the circumstances and rationale to the BPP for ratification.
questions.explanation: Emergency procurement must be subject to immediate audit and ratification by submitting a report detailing the necessity to the BPP [50].

questions.question: Which section provides for the use of a **Framework Agreement** for repeated acquisitions of commonly used goods or services over a specified period?
questions.explanation: Section 44 provides for Framework Agreements for repeated procurements under pre-agreed terms [51].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA mandates that procuring entities must treat all bidders fairly and equitably?
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires equal and fair treatment of all bidders during the procurement process [52].

questions.question: What is the role of the National Council on Public Procurement (NCPP)?
options: To award all contracts above â‚¦5 billion.
To resolve industrial disputes in the public service.
To provide high-level policy direction and oversight to the BPP.
To manage the Federal Government's Treasury Single Account (TSA).
questions.explanation: The NCPP provides policy direction and high-level oversight of the BPP, reporting directly to the President.

questions.question: Which procurement method must be used if competition is limited to a few suppliers but price quotations are obtained from them, requiring BPP approval?
questions.explanation: Restricted Tendering (Section 40) is the method that invites a limited, pre-qualified group of vendors to compete [34], [53].

questions.question: Procurement planning is essential because it ensures the MDA avoids:
questions.explanation: Proper planning is critical to align needs with budget (Section 14) and prevent illegal Contract Splitting (Section 16) [26], [22].

questions.question: Procurement requiring advice on organizational restructuring or technical feasibility falls under:
questions.explanation: Advisory and intellectual tasks are classified as Consultancy Services (Section 43) [38].

questions.question: Which section requires procuring entities to publish advertisements for all procurements above specified thresholds in national newspapers?
questions.explanation: Section 23 requires mandatory advertisement of procurement opportunities above thresholds to ensure transparency [54], [55], [56].

questions.question: What is the minimum statutory advertisement period required for bidding opportunities under national competitive bidding?
questions.explanation: Section 25 requires at least 4 weeks for submission of bids under national competitive bidding [57].

questions.question: The procurement objective that encourages community participation in small-scale, localized projects is provided for in:
questions.explanation: Section 39 provides for community participation in small-scale procurement to encourage local development [58].

questions.question: What happens if a procuring entity violates the PPA by failing to ensure due process and transparency?
options: The BPP must issue a commendation.
The Accounting Officer faces disciplinary action, including potential dismissal or surcharge.
The contract automatically defaults to the cheapest bidder.
The National Assembly must disband the MDA.
questions.explanation: Violations of the PPA constitute serious misconduct, leading to severe sanctions (surcharge, dismissal, or criminal charges) against the Accounting Officer or responsible procurement official [59], [60].

questions.question: The Ministerial Tenders Board (MTB) has the authority to approve contracts that fall **below** the ceiling set by the:
questions.explanation: Contracts exceeding the MTB threshold must be reviewed and approved by the Federal Executive Council (FEC) [61], [43], [48].

questions.question: The BPPâ€™s mandate to maintain a national database of contractors (Section 9) primarily supports which procurement objective?
options: Tracking contractor performance and verifying eligibility/capacity.
questions.explanation: The database monitors performance and facilitates sanctions like blacklisting, while ensuring bidders meet eligibility requirements (Section 16) [12].

questions.question: Which term describes the sequential documentation of financial and procurement transactions, ensuring integrity and traceability for verification?
questions.explanation: The Audit Trail provides a chronological record of transactions, vital for accountability and traceability, which is supported by the 5-year record retention rule [62], [44].

questions.question: The three main classes of procurement defined under the PPA are:
questions.explanation: The PPA fundamentally categorizes all acquisition into Goods, Works, and Services [38].

questions.question: For small value purchases below the competitive threshold, strict financial regulations typically mandate that the MDA must obtain a minimum of:
questions.explanation: Although the PPA favors open bidding, supplementary financial guidelines require at least three quotations for small purchases to ensure basic value for money [63].

questions.question: What is the statutory penalty for a procurement officer found guilty of violating the PPA, such as abuse of office or contract splitting?
options: A promotion to a non-procurement post.
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes imprisonment and fines for serious procurement-related fraud and breaches by officials and contractors [64], [65].

questions.question: The power of the BPP to cancel a procurement proceeding before contract award if irregularities are found (Section 53) reinforces the principle of:
questions.explanation: Section 53 empowers the BPP to suspend or cancel proceedings, directly enforcing Due Process and holding the MDA accountable for irregularities [66], [67].

subcategories.name: Bidding, Evaluation & Award
subcategories.description: Bidding processes, evaluation criteria, bid opening, and contract awards

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 requires public advertisement of procurement opportunities above specified thresholds?
questions.explanation: Section 23 requires the advertisement of all procurements above the set thresholds to ensure transparency [1-3].

questions.question: What is the minimum statutory time frame required for the submission of bids under National Competitive Bidding (NCB)?
questions.explanation: Section 25 requires at least 4 weeks (28 days) for the submission of bids under national competitive bidding [4].

questions.question: All standard bidding documents (SBDs) used by MDAs must be based on templates issued by which body?
options: Office of the Head of Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: Section 25 requires procuring entities to use standard bidding documents containing clear specifications and criteria, typically issued by the BPP [5].

questions.question: The process of verifying a bidder's technical capacity and qualifications *before* they are invited to submit bids is known as:
questions.explanation: Section 22 provides for pre-qualification of bidders to ensure capability before the formal submission of bids [6].

questions.question: According to the PPA, which financial document must bidders submit as a mandatory eligibility requirement, typically covering the preceding three years?
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires bidders to have fulfilled all tax obligations, necessitating the submission of a valid Tax Clearance Certificate (TCC) [7].

questions.question: Under Section 16, which condition disqualifies a contractor from being considered an eligible bidder?
options: Having been in operation for less than one year
Being in receivership, bankruptcy, or insolvency
Using sub-contractors for part of the work
questions.explanation: Section 16 states that eligible contractors must not be in receivership, bankruptcy, or insolvency [8].

questions.question: What is the primary function of a **Bid Security**?
options: To guarantee the contractor's performance after award.
To prevent bidders from withdrawing their tender before the expiration of the validity period.
To cover the government's cost of preparing bidding documents.
To serve as the mobilization fee.
questions.explanation: Section 28 requires bid security to protect procuring entities from default, such as withdrawal or failure to sign a contract, by bidders [9, 10].

questions.question: What is the typical validity period for bids, unless otherwise specified in the tender documents?
questions.explanation: Section 26 provides that bids shall remain valid for 60 days unless otherwise stated [9].

questions.question: The Bid Opening ceremony must be conducted in public to ensure transparency, as required by which section of the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 27 requires that bid opening must be done publicly to ensure fairness and transparency [11].

questions.question: Immediately following a public bid opening, which documents must be recorded in the official minutes?
options: The BPP's final No Objection Certificate.
The names of all bidders and the bid prices.
The political affiliation of the bidders.
questions.explanation: Bid opening minutes must record the names of bidders, bid prices, and modifications or withdrawals to ensure transparency [11].

questions.question: A bid that complies fully with all technical, financial, and administrative requirements stipulated in the tender document is defined as a:
questions.explanation: A responsive bid is one that complies fully with all criteria stated in the bid document and is eligible for evaluation [12-14].

questions.question: Which section mandates that the evaluation of bids must be based strictly on criteria and specifications stated in the solicitation documents?
questions.explanation: Section 33 mandates that evaluation of bids must be based strictly on criteria stated in solicitation documents [15, 16].

questions.question: After the public opening of bids, which action is expressly prohibited under the PPA regarding procurement documents?
options: Recording the price in the minutes.
Altering or modifying the substance of the bids.
questions.explanation: Section 33 prohibits the alteration of procurement documents or bids once they have been opened [17].

questions.question: The standard evaluation process for goods and works typically involves how many distinct stages?
options: Four stages (Initial, Mid-term, Final, and Post-audit)
questions.explanation: Bid evaluation is generally conducted in two stages: technical evaluation (compliance with specifications) and financial evaluation (price comparison) [18, 19].

questions.question: The final contract award recommendation must be made to the bidder who submitted the:
options: Bid with the longest execution time.
Bid from the most senior contractor.
questions.explanation: Section 33 requires awarding the contract to the lowest evaluated responsive bid to ensure value for money and compliance [20, 21].

questions.question: If a contract is awarded, which MDA official is statutorily designated as the signatory on behalf of the procuring entity?
options: The Director of Finance and Accounts.
questions.explanation: The Accounting Officer (Permanent Secretary/CEO) is designated as the contract signatory, formalizing the legal agreement [13].

questions.question: What is the maximum percentage of the contract sum allowable as a Mobilization Fee (advance payment) to a contractor?
questions.explanation: The mobilization fee is limited to a maximum of 30% of the contract sum [22-26].

questions.question: The disbursement of the mobilization fee is conditional upon the contractor providing a(n):
questions.explanation: Mobilization fees are paid subject to the contractor providing a Performance Bond or Advance Payment Guarantee to secure the funds [23, 25, 26].

questions.question: Performance Security (or bond) is required under Section 29 to ensure the contractor fulfills which obligation?
options: To complete the works or services as specified in the contract.
questions.explanation: Section 29 requires Performance Securities to ensure contractors fulfill their contractual obligations [25, 27].

questions.question: If all bids received by a procuring entity fail to meet the required technical or administrative standards, the procuring entity may invoke which measure?
options: Award the contract to the highest bidder.
Reject all bids and cancel the procurement proceedings.
Negotiate secretly with the cheapest bidder.
Transfer the project to another MDA.
questions.explanation: Section 31 allows rejection of all bids if none meets the required standards or criteria, leading to cancellation of the proceeding [28].

questions.question: Which section requires that contract award decisions must be communicated to unsuccessful bidders?
questions.explanation: Section 30 requires notifying unsuccessful bidders of the contract award decisions to ensure transparency [29].

questions.question: The BPP is empowered to suspend procurement proceedings if irregularities are found, as provided in:
questions.explanation: Section 53 empowers the BPP to suspend or cancel procurement if irregularities are detected, reinforcing due process [30].

questions.question: In the evaluation process, the technical evaluation aims to assess the bidder's:
options: Capacity, experience, and compliance with technical specifications.
questions.explanation: Technical evaluation checks the bidderâ€™s capacity, experience, and compliance with the MDAâ€™s detailed technical specifications [19].

questions.question: If a bidder fails the technical evaluation stage, they are typically excluded from the:
questions.explanation: Only technically responsive bidders proceed to the financial evaluation stage, ensuring only qualified firms compete on price.

questions.question: Which officer is typically tasked with verifying the adequacy of the Bid Security submitted by a contractor?
questions.explanation: The Procurement Officer manages technical and administrative compliance, including verifying the validity and adequacy of the bid security.

questions.question: The PPA ensures that all bid opening procedures adhere to transparency by requiring minutes to be recorded and signed by representatives of:
options: The MDA, the BPP, and the bidders present.
questions.explanation: Bid opening minutes must be signed by the procuring entity, BPP representatives, and the bidders present to authenticate the process.

questions.question: Which section requires procuring entities to use standard bidding documents containing clear specifications and criteria?
questions.explanation: Section 25 stipulates the contents and requirements for standard bidding documents [5].

questions.question: A bidder who fails to submit a valid Tax Clearance Certificate (TCC) must be classified as:
questions.explanation: Failure to meet statutory eligibility criteria, such as TCC submission (Section 16), renders the bidder ineligible [7].

questions.question: If a bid security expires during the evaluation process, what is the required administrative action?
options: The MDA must award the contract immediately.
The bidder must be automatically disqualified.
The MDA must request the bidder to extend the validity period.
The MDA must notify the FEC.
questions.explanation: The PPA generally requires bids and bid securities to remain valid throughout the process; if the validity lapses, the bidder must be requested to extend it to remain eligible.

questions.question: Contract negotiations are permitted in which type of procurement method under the PPA?
options: Only in Sole Sourcing or when technical bids are not entirely satisfactory (Section 36).
For all Works projects above â‚¦50 million.
Only for contracts approved by the FEC.
questions.explanation: Section 36 permits negotiations only under limited circumstances, such as single-source procurement or where technical aspects need refinement, but are generally prohibited in competitive bidding [31].

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the financial evaluation stage?
options: To assess the bidder's past performance.
To verify the contractor's technical compliance.
To compare the cost-effectiveness and price of the responsive bids.
To decide on the mobilization fee.
questions.explanation: The financial evaluation compares the pricing of the technically qualified bids to determine the lowest evaluated price, supporting value for money [19].

questions.question: An Abnormally Low Bid identified during evaluation must be flagged because it may suggest:
options: A potential risk of contract abandonment or poor quality execution.
The MDA provided too much information.
questions.explanation: Abnormally Low Bids are flagged for investigation as they suggest the bidder may be unable to complete the work as specified, leading to later abandonment or quality issues [32].

questions.question: For a contract to be awarded, the procuring entity must first obtain the BPP's:
questions.explanation: Section 5 mandates the BPP to issue a 'Certificate of No Objection' for high-value procurements before a contract award is finalized [33-35].

questions.question: The public announcement of awarded contracts above a certain threshold is required by which section of the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires the publication of contract awards above thresholds to ensure transparency [36, 37].

questions.question: Within how many working days must an aggrieved bidder submit a complaint after becoming aware of the grounds for complaint?
questions.explanation: Section 54 provides a complaint mechanism, requiring prompt submission of complaints to the Complaint Review Committee [35, 38-41].

questions.question: Which body is responsible for managing administrative review of procurement complaints filed by aggrieved bidders?
options: The Office of the Secretary to the Government of the Federation (SGF).
questions.explanation: The Procurement Complaint Review Committee provides an administrative avenue for dispute resolution before litigation [35, 38, 41, 42].

questions.question: If a procuring entity cancels a procurement proceeding before contract award (Section 31), what must they do next?
options: Immediately publish notice of the cancellation.
Transfer the funds to another project.
questions.explanation: Section 31 requires the publication of the notice of cancellation to maintain transparency [17, 28].

questions.question: The use of **Pre-qualification** (Section 22) is primarily intended to exclude bidders who lack:
options: The required technical and professional capacity.
questions.explanation: Pre-qualification checks professional and technical capacity early to ensure only capable bidders proceed to tender [6, 43].

questions.question: In the procurement of Consultancy Services, which method is typically used to ensure both competence and reasonable cost?
questions.explanation: Consultancy Services (Section 43) often utilize Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) to balance technical merit with price [44].

questions.question: Which document is required before final payment is processed to confirm satisfactory delivery of goods or services?
questions.explanation: No payment is processed without the Job Completion Certificate (JCC), confirming satisfactory delivery and acceptance [12, 45-47].

questions.question: In evaluation, the rule of 'Domestic Preference' (Section 35) means that:
options: Nigerian firms may receive a scoring advantage or margin of preference.
The contract must be split among local firms.
questions.explanation: Section 35 allows for domestic preference, giving a marginal scoring advantage to encourage local industry [19, 48, 49].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA mandates that procuring entities must retain procurement documents for at least 5 years?
questions.explanation: Section 38 requires procurement documents to be retained for at least 5 years to support potential audits and inquiries [50, 51].

questions.question: If a bidder attempts to influence the evaluation process through bribery or collusion, they are subject to penalties prescribed in which section?
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes penalties for fraudulent and corrupt practices like bribery, collusion, and bid rigging [52-56].

questions.question: Which entity typically verifies whether a contractor has a criminal conviction for fraud before awarding a contract?
options: The Budget Office of the Federation.
The BPP and the Code of Conduct Bureau (CCB).
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires bidders to have no criminal record for fraud, verified through the BPP's database and regulatory checks [44, 57].

questions.question: What is the primary consequence for a contractor who fails to provide the required Performance Bond after contract award?
options: The MDA must proceed with the contract without security.
The MDA must seek BPP approval to vary the contract.
questions.explanation: Failure to submit the mandated Performance Bond (Section 29) to secure government payment typically leads to contract termination, as the government is exposed to risk.

questions.question: In the evaluation process, what is the required administrative step taken if a bidder's offer is determined to be non-responsive?
options: The MDA must engage in negotiation with that bidder.
The MDA must notify the BPP immediately and exclude the bid from further evaluation.
The bidder must be given 48 hours to correct the error.
questions.explanation: Non-responsive bids, lacking mandatory requirements, are excluded immediately from further consideration to maintain the integrity of the process.

questions.question: The requirement for using **Standard Bidding Documents (SBDs)** (Section 25) aims to enhance which principles?
options: Standardization and equal treatment of bidders.
questions.explanation: SBDs promote uniform procedures, clarity, and ensure equal treatment of all bidders (Section 16) by standardizing required formats [44].

questions.question: What is the mandatory action required by the Accounting Officer upon contract award, concerning the Procurement Journal?
options: The contract details must be published promptly.
The contract must be kept secret for security reasons.
The BPP must waive the publication requirement.
Only the winnerâ€™s name must be published.
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires publication of the contract award in the Procurement Journal to ensure transparency [36, 51].

questions.question: Which section allows a procuring entity to reject all bids if it is determined that the prices quoted are substantially in excess of the estimated budget or market price?
questions.explanation: Section 31 allows the rejection of all bids if there is insufficient competition, bids are too high, or a major irregularity is detected [28].

questions.question: The **Post-Qualification Audit** (BPP practice) verifies which critical element after bid opening but before contract award?
options: The bidder's continued eligibility, technical claims, and financial capacity.
The amount of the mobilization fee.
questions.explanation: Post-Qualification is a BPP practice involving the review of the bidderâ€™s documentation (Section 16) to confirm continued eligibility and capacity after bid opening [58, 59].

subcategories.name: Transparency, Ethics, & Accountability
subcategories.description: Transparency requirements, ethical standards, conflict of interest, and oversight mechanisms

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 prohibits conflict of interest and mandates disclosure by officials?
questions.explanation: Section 57 strictly prohibits conflict of interest in procurement proceedings and requires mandatory disclosure by procurement officials [1, 2].

questions.question: The intentional act of fixing or manipulating bid outcomes to restrict competition is known as collusion or bid rigging, which is prohibited under which section?
questions.explanation: Section 58 prohibits fraudulent practices, including conspiracy to rig bids and collusion among bidders [3-5].

questions.question: What is the consequence for a procurement officer found guilty of an offense under Section 58 (e.g., fraud or bid rigging)?
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes penalties, including imprisonment and fines, for procurement-related fraud and breaches by officials and contractors [4, 6].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 mandates that all procurement decisions must be properly documented and recorded?
questions.explanation: Section 34 requires that all procurement decisions, including reasons for the chosen method and rejection of bids, must be properly documented [7].

questions.question: Procurement documents and records must be retained by the procuring entity for a minimum period of:
questions.explanation: Section 38 requires that all procurement documents be retained for a minimum of 5 years to facilitate audit and inspection [8].

questions.question: The PPA principle of accountability is supported by the requirement to publish all contracts awarded above a specific threshold in the:
questions.explanation: Section 12 mandates the establishment and publication of procurement journals to ensure wide dissemination of information regarding contracts awarded, supporting transparency [9].

questions.question: The BPP is statutorily empowered to blacklist or permanently exclude contractors who commit offenses under Section 58. This is based on sanctions provided in:
questions.explanation: Section 57 empowers the BPP to blacklist bidders for engaging in corrupt practices [2, 10].

questions.question: The principle of transparency in bid opening (Section 27) requires the procurement entity to record and sign the minutes in the presence of:
options: Only the Accounting Officer and the Minister
The BPP representative and the bidders present
The Head of Civil Service and the Auditor-General
questions.explanation: To ensure fairness, bid opening minutes must be authenticated by the Procuring Entity, BPP (or relevant body), and the bidders present.

questions.question: The core principle requiring all bidders to be treated without prejudice or discrimination throughout the process is enshrined in which section?
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires equal and fair treatment of all bidders during procurement, ensuring transparency and fairness [11].

questions.question: The Accounting Officer (Permanent Secretary) is ultimately responsible for compliance, financial integrity, and accountability in procurement because they:
options: Are designated the Chief Accounting Officer for the MDA
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/CEO is the Chief Accounting Officer, holding ultimate personal responsibility for expenditure control and compliance [12, 13].

questions.question: An officer involved in procurement who receives confidential information and uses it for personal financial advantage violates which ethical mandate?
questions.explanation: Using official information for personal gain is strictly prohibited, falling under the conflict of interest rule (Section 57 PPA and PSR Chapter 15) [14].

questions.question: The system put in place to ensure integrity and traceability of all financial decisions and documentation throughout the procurement cycle is called the:
questions.explanation: The Audit Trail provides a chronological record of transactions, allowing auditors to verify integrity and traceability, ensuring accountability [15].

questions.question: Section 58 explicitly forbids the illegal breaking down of contracts to avoid higher authority approval, a practice termed:
questions.explanation: Contract splitting is a form of procurement fraud prohibited under Section 58(4), designed to circumvent statutory approval thresholds [16].

questions.question: Which body is responsible for conducting procurement audits of MDAs to ensure compliance with the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 6 empowers the BPP to conduct procurement audits of procuring entities to monitor compliance [17].

questions.question: An officer who fails to report an offer of bribe or inducement immediately to the appropriate authority violates ethical standards under which PSR Chapter?
questions.explanation: Chapter 15 emphasizes integrity and mandates immediate reporting of bribes to the appropriate authority [18, 19].

questions.question: The legal action that enables the government to recover the exact amount of financial loss caused by an officerâ€™s negligence or misconduct is known as:
questions.explanation: Surcharge is the recovery of government losses from the officer's pay, applied when the loss is due to the officerâ€™s fault [20, 21].

questions.question: What is the consequence for an officer who fails the Confirmation Examination after three consecutive attempts?
options: Required to resign or be withdrawn from the service
questions.explanation: Rule 030104 states that an Officer who fails the confirmation examination after three consecutive attempts shall be required to resign or be withdrawn from the service [22, 23].

questions.question: The principle of **accountability** in procurement is primarily supported by which BPP practice after bid opening?
questions.explanation: The Post-Qualification Audit involves reviewing the bidderâ€™s documentation to verify their continued technical and financial eligibility *after* bid opening, ensuring compliance [24, 25].

questions.question: The body responsible for monitoring compliance with anti-corruption laws and enforcing ethical standards in public finance (excluding financial crime prosecution) is the:
questions.explanation: The ICPC monitors compliance with anti-corruption laws and investigates institutional corruption and ethical breaches [26-28].

questions.question: An officer under **Interdiction** receives:
questions.explanation: During interdiction (temporary suspension pending investigation), an officer is placed on half salary (Rule 020412) [29, 30].

questions.question: Which document must be published promptly to fulfill the transparency requirement regarding contract awards?
questions.explanation: The publication of contract details in the Procurement Journal (Section 12/32) ensures transparency after award [9, 31].

questions.question: The use of **Standard Bidding Documents (SBDs)**, issued by the BPP, supports transparency by ensuring:
options: The cheapest price is always achieved.
Uniformity and clarity of requirements for all potential bidders.
Negotiation is mandatory for all bids.
questions.explanation: SBDs promote uniform procedures, clarity, and equal treatment of all bidders, supporting the principles of transparency and fairness (Section 25) [32].

questions.question: Which specific PSR Chapter provides the foundation for integrity, neutrality, and accountability in public service conduct?
questions.explanation: Chapter 15 of the PSR (or Chapter 10 of PSR 2021 cited in the source) deals specifically with Public Service Conduct and Ethics, emphasizing integrity and accountability [33, 34].

questions.question: Misconduct involving the Falsification of Records is classified under the PSR as a:
questions.explanation: Falsification of records, along with fraud and corruption, constitutes Serious Misconduct, potentially leading to dismissal (Rule 100401) [35, 36].

questions.question: What is the mandatory frequency for an officer to declare their assets under the Code of Conduct for Public Officers?
options: Every four years, and upon assumption of duty
questions.explanation: Asset declaration is required upon assumption of duty and every four years thereafter, as mandated by the Fifth Schedule of the Constitution [37-40].

questions.question: Which agency is primarily responsible for enforcing the asset declaration rules across the public service?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau (CCB) receives and verifies public officersâ€™ asset declarations [41, 42].

questions.question: The loss of government funds or property must be communicated immediately to which three offices (among others) for proper fiscal accountability and investigation?
options: Permanent Secretary, Legal Department, and Revenue Collector
questions.explanation: Mandatory loss reporting requires notification to the Police, Accountant-General, and Auditor-General for criminal and fiscal accountability [43].

questions.question: The PPA principle of **transparency** directly supports the constitutional right of citizens to access information, as formalized by the:
questions.explanation: The PPA's transparency mandates complement the FOI Act, which grants citizens the right to request public records [44].

questions.question: Who has the final authority to discipline Directors (GL 17) in the Federal Civil Service?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: The Civil Service Commission is the disciplinary authority for Directors (GL 17) and officers on GL 07 and above [45-47].

questions.question: Which section provides penalties for procurement fraud, collusion, and misrepresentation?
questions.explanation: Section 58 covers procurement offenses, ensuring penalties for fraudulent and corrupt practices [3-6, 48].

questions.question: What is the penalty for an officer who engages in political activities while in service?
options: A transfer to a political post
questions.explanation: Public officers are prohibited from engaging in any political activities; violations lead to disciplinary action (PSR Chapter 10) [49, 50].

questions.question: The requirement that all funds must be checked in the Vote Book before commitment is made serves as an internal control against:
questions.explanation: Checking the Vote Book (Expenditure Ledger) is mandatory to ensure the remaining balance is adequate, serving as a first line of defense against Over-Expenditure [51, 52].

questions.question: When an MDA cancels a procurement proceeding due to irregularities (Section 31), which administrative step must follow promptly to maintain transparency?
options: The Accounting Officer must be interdicted.
The MDA must publish a notice of the cancellation.
The BPP must immediately award the contract to the next bidder.
questions.explanation: Section 31 requires the procuring entity to publish a notice of the cancellation immediately to ensure transparency and accountability [31].

questions.question: Which agency is responsible for investigating and prosecuting financial crimes, fraud, and money laundering related to public funds?
questions.explanation: The EFCC investigates and prosecutes financial crimes, fraud, and money laundering [26, 53-55].

questions.question: The segregation of dutiesâ€”where no single officer controls all three functions of approval, custody, and recordingâ€”is a fundamental control measure against:
questions.explanation: Segregation of Duties is the primary internal control measure used to minimize fraud risk by separating approval, custody, and record-keeping roles [56].

questions.question: The penalty of **Dismissal** for serious misconduct results in:
options: Forfeiture of all claims to retirement benefits
Demotion to the next lower grade level
questions.explanation: Dismissal is the ultimate disciplinary penalty (Rule 100401) and leads to the permanent removal from service and forfeiture of most benefits [57, 58].

questions.question: Which section requires the Accounting Officer to take into account the gravity of the shortcoming and the quality of the officer's previous service when deciding whether to withhold or defer an increment?
questions.explanation: Rule 040204 mandates the Accounting Officer to weigh the gravity of the misconduct against past service when deciding between deferment and the more severe sanction of withholding increment [59].

questions.question: Under the PPA, the term **'Responsive Bid'** relates directly to transparency and accountability by confirming that the bid:
options: Meets all technical, financial, and administrative requirements.
Is submitted by an FCT-based contractor.
questions.explanation: A responsive bid is one that complies fully with all specifications and eligibility criteria, making it suitable for subsequent financial comparison [60, 61].

questions.question: The legal backing for the government's centralization of all revenues into the Treasury Single Account (TSA) promotes financial accountability by ensuring:
options: Consolidated cash visibility and elimination of leakages.
The expansion of capital projects only.
questions.explanation: TSA consolidates government accounts, ensuring unified cash management, transparency, and blocking revenue leakages [52, 62-64].

questions.question: The prohibition on using official information for personal gain is a core ethical principle under which constitutional instrument?
questions.explanation: The Fifth Schedule of the Constitution (Code of Conduct) mandates ethical standards, including avoiding conflict of interest and misuse of official information [65, 66].

questions.question: An officer on **Suspension** pending investigation into gross misconduct receives:
questions.explanation: Suspended officers generally do not earn salaries (Rule 100406) [67-71].

questions.question: The mandatory requirement for contractors to submit a valid Tax Clearance Certificate (TCC) for the preceding three years ensures compliance with:
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires bidders to have fulfilled all obligations regarding taxes, pensions, and social security, confirmed via TCC submission [72, 73].

questions.question: Who must certify that funds are available in the budget before any expenditure or commitment is legally incurred?
questions.explanation: The Vote Controller certifies that funds are available before incurring expenditure, controlling the obligation against the Vote Book [74, 75].

questions.question: In line with the PPA and the PSR, an officer must not accept paid employment during absence from duty without:
options: The express approval of the Head of the Civil Service (OHCSF)
A written letter from the Minister of Finance
questions.explanation: An officer on leave of absence shall not accept any paid employment without previously obtaining the express approval of the Office of the Head of the Civil Service (OHCSF) [19, 76, 77].

questions.question: The final legislative oversight check on past government expenditure and procurement integrity is performed by the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) based on the report submitted by the:
options: Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: The Auditor-General reports on public accounts and unauthorized expenditure, which is the primary basis for PAC oversight [78-80].

questions.question: Who must receive notification when an officer is charged with a criminal offense, under the PSR requirements for conduct and accountability?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
The officerâ€™s Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office
The Chief Judge of the Federal High Court
questions.explanation: An Officer must promptly report to his Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office whenever he is charged with a criminal offense [81].

questions.question: What is the maximum penalty for a breach of the Code of Conduct for Public Officers, as stipulated in the Constitution?
options: Dismissal, imprisonment, and disqualification from holding public office
Only a written warning and loss of one year's increment
Demotion in rank and transfer to a lower-grade ministry
questions.explanation: Code of Conduct violations can lead to dismissal, imprisonment, and disqualification from holding public office [82, 83].

questions.question: Which specific PSR Rule covers the penalty of **Loss of Pay** for unauthorized absence from duty?
questions.explanation: Rule 040206 allows salary to be withheld in cases of unauthorized absence [69, 84].

questions.question: Which body is responsible for regulating, monitoring, and enforcing compliance with the Public Procurement Act, thereby guaranteeing accountability across MDAs?
questions.explanation: The BPP regulates and monitors public procurement processes and ensures due process is followed [85-87].

questions.question: Which term describes the authority of the BPP to halt proceedings before contract award if procedural or ethical irregularities are detected?
options: Suspension or Cancellation of Proceedings (Section 53 implied)
questions.explanation: The BPP has the authority (Section 53 implied) to suspend or cancel proceedings if irregularities are detected, ensuring due process and transparency [31].

subcategories.name: Eligibility, Consultants & Budgeting
subcategories.description: Eligibility criteria for bidders, consultant services procurement, budgetary alignment, and planning mandates

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 mandates that contractors must possess the professional and technical qualifications necessary for contract execution?
questions.explanation: Section 16 mandates that bidders must have the requisite professional and technical capacity and qualifications to perform contracts [1, 2].

questions.question: A mandatory eligibility requirement under Section 16 is that contractors must not be in which financial condition?
options: Having operated for less than one year.
questions.explanation: Section 16 states that eligible contractors must not be in receivership, bankruptcy, or insolvency [3, 4].

questions.question: What is the mandatory eligibility document required under Section 16 to confirm fulfillment of tax obligations?
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires bidders to have fulfilled obligations regarding taxes, pensions, and social security contributions, typically confirmed via TCC [4].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 requires bidders to have no record of criminal conviction for fraud, corruption, or misrepresentation?
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires bidders to have no record of criminal conviction for fraud, corruption, or misrepresentation [5].

questions.question: The process of verifying a bidder's technical capacity *after* the bid opening but *before* contract award is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Post-Qualification is a BPP practice involving the review of bidderâ€™s documentation to confirm eligibility after bid opening [6].

questions.question: If a procurement officer discovers a bidder has submitted a fraudulent Tax Clearance Certificate (TCC), the bidder is immediately classified as:
questions.explanation: Fraudulent submission violates eligibility criteria (Section 16) and procurement ethics (Section 58), rendering the bidder ineligible [4, 5].

questions.question: What must the Accounting Officer ensure regarding contractors who are debarred or blacklisted by the BPP?
options: They are still eligible for small contracts.
They are automatically excluded from all tenders.
They are only excluded from works contracts.
questions.explanation: Section 57 empowers the BPP to debar/blacklist contractors for malpractice, meaning they are excluded from all public tenders [7, 8].

questions.question: Section 16 of the PPA requires contractors to possess which type of capacity, in addition to technical and professional competence?
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires contractors to demonstrate financial capability alongside technical qualifications as part of eligibility criteria [2, 3].

questions.question: What is the consequence if a contractor fails to provide the required Performance Bond after a contract is awarded?
options: The MDA assumes the financial risk.
The contract is transferred to the next bidder.
questions.explanation: Failure to submit the mandated Performance Bond (Section 29) to secure government payment typically leads to contract termination, as the government is exposed to risk [9].

questions.question: Pre-qualification (Section 22) is primarily used to check the bidder's capacity *before* issuing tender documents, thereby saving resources during:
questions.explanation: Pre-qualification ensures that only technically capable bidders receive and respond to the full tender, streamlining the subsequent bid evaluation process [10].

questions.question: Procurement involving advisory, intellectual, or highly specialized tasks falls under the classification of:
questions.explanation: Consultancy Services cover specialized intellectual or advisory tasks (Section 43) [11].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 covers the specific procedures for procuring consultant services?
questions.explanation: Section 43 provides procedures for procuring consultant services, including selection and negotiation [11].

questions.question: The primary selection method used for high-value consultancy services that prioritizes both technical expertise and reasonable cost is:
questions.explanation: Consultancy Services often use Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) to balance technical merit with financial proposal (Section 43 implied).

questions.question: For a simple or standard consultancy assignment where technical qualifications are similar, which selection method might be preferred to emphasize efficiency?
questions.explanation: Least Cost Selection (LCS) is used for simple tasks where technical inputs are standardized.

questions.question: Section 45 provides for the engagement of procurement consultants to assist procuring entities in:
options: Preparation of technical specifications and evaluation.
questions.explanation: Section 45 provides for the engagement of procurement consultants to assist MDAs, usually in specialized areas like technical specifications [12].

questions.question: Unlike bidding for goods and works, consultants are often evaluated using which specific document?
questions.explanation: Request for Proposals (RFP) is the standard solicitation document used for consulting services, requiring technical and financial proposals.

questions.question: What is the significance of the technical proposal submission for consulting services?
options: It is used only for price comparison.
It is graded first to ensure competence before financial proposals are opened.
It is discarded if the price is too high.
questions.explanation: Consultancy selection involves a two-stage opening: technical proposals are evaluated and graded first, and only qualified proposals proceed to financial opening.

questions.question: What procurement method should be used if the estimated cost of consultancy services is below the threshold for competitive bidding and requires specialized expertise?
questions.explanation: Direct Negotiation or Single Source is permitted for highly specialized consultancy services where only one source is capable or available (Section 42 implied).

questions.question: In the context of consultancy, which ethical concern must be verified before engaging a firm that previously helped the MDA draft the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the same project?
questions.explanation: A firm that prepares the ToR is often barred from bidding on the resulting contract due to a conflict of interest, ensuring fairness (Section 57).

questions.question: When procuring consulting services, the evaluation should place the highest weight on:
options: The technical quality, methodology, and key personnel.
questions.explanation: Quality (technical merit) is paramount for consulting services, followed by cost (QCBS principle).

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 strictly prohibits a procuring entity from initiating procurement without approved budgetary provision?
questions.explanation: Section 14 prohibits procurement without approved budgetary provision and availability of funds [13-15].

questions.question: Procurement planning, according to Section 14, must be aligned with:
questions.explanation: Procurement planning must be aligned with appropriated budget provisions to ensure fiscal responsibility and fund availability [16].

questions.question: The illegal practice of **Contract Splitting** is typically performed to circumvent which mandatory constraint?
options: The need for high-level approval (MTB/FEC) thresholds.
questions.explanation: Contract Splitting is prohibited (Section 16, 58(4)) as it undermines transparency and circumvents established approval thresholds [17, 18].

questions.question: Before any financial commitment (like issuing an LPO) related to procurement is made, what document must be checked to confirm fund availability in the relevant subhead?
questions.explanation: The Vote Book (FR 601) must be checked daily to ensure the commitment is within the legal capacity of the approved budget [19, 20].

questions.question: Who, as the chief fiscal officer, is personally responsible for controlling the procurement budget and ensuring compliance with Section 14?
options: The Head of the Procurement Unit.
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/CEO is the Chief Accounting Officer, holding personal responsibility for budget compliance and expenditure control [21, 22].

questions.question: The process by which funds are legally moved between budget subheads within the same expenditure head is known as:
questions.explanation: Virement is the authorized transfer of funds from one sub-head to another within the same head of expenditure [23].

questions.question: Any request for Virement related to a procurement project must be formally authorized by which document?
questions.explanation: Virement must be formally approved and backed by a Virement Warrant [24-26].

questions.question: If an MDA incurs expenditure on procurement that exceeds the approved budget for that subhead, this is categorized as:
questions.explanation: Spending that surpasses the approved budget is classified as an Excess Vote or unauthorized expenditure [25, 27, 28].

questions.question: The MDAâ€™s Procurement Planning Committee (PPC) ensures procurement items are correctly classified as Goods, Works, or Services, as required by:
questions.explanation: The PPA classifies procurement into three main categories: Goods, Works, and Services (Implied by the definitions in the PPA framework).

questions.question: The **Treasury Single Account (TSA)** system directly aids procurement integrity by ensuring:
options: All contracts are awarded to local vendors.
Fund availability is verifiable before any commitment.
Staff are paid half salary during procurement.
questions.explanation: TSA consolidates government accounts, providing cash visibility and confirming fund liquidity, which is crucial for Section 14 compliance [29, 30].

questions.question: What is the consequence for a bidder who attempts to influence the evaluation committee through unauthorized means (Section 58)?
options: Blacklisting from all future federal tenders.
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes sanctions for fraudulent practices, including blacklisting, ensuring integrity in the evaluation phase [31-34].

questions.question: If a consulting firm fails to provide evidence of fulfilling its tax obligations (TCC), the firm must be:
options: Awarded the contract based on technical score.
questions.explanation: Failure to provide mandatory eligibility documents (Section 16) means the firm is non-responsive and must be excluded from evaluation [4].

questions.question: Which specific document sets the detailed spending limits and approval authority for MDA Accounting Officers and Ministerial Tenders Boards?
questions.explanation: The BPP establishes and publishes the Threshold Manual, setting approval limits for Accounting Officers and Tender Boards [35, 36].

questions.question: Consultancy procurement differs from Goods/Works procurement primarily in the emphasis placed on:
questions.explanation: Consultancy prioritizes technical capacity and quality highly, often using QCBS, unlike Goods/Works where lowest responsive bid on price is key.

questions.question: The PPA's provision for pre-qualification (Section 22) supports the principle of **Value for Money** by ensuring:
options: The most expensive bid is chosen.
Only bidders who meet technical standards are considered for the financial stage.
questions.explanation: By checking technical competence early, the MDA ensures that subsequent price competition is among genuinely capable firms, leading to better Value for Money [10].

questions.question: If an officer is found guilty of authorizing expenditure beyond the available appropriation (Excess Vote), they are liable to face:
options: Disciplinary sanctions, including surcharge or dismissal.
questions.explanation: Unauthorized expenditure and financial misconduct attract sanctions, including surcharge to recover the loss or dismissal for serious breaches [37-39].

questions.question: Procurement of specialized software customization or system integration typically falls under which classification?
questions.explanation: Specialized intellectual or technical integration tasks are usually classified as Consultancy Services.

questions.question: Section 16 of the PPA requires contractors to demonstrate compliance with social security obligations, primarily covering:
options: Remittance of pension and other employee contributions.
questions.explanation: Section 16 mandates that bidders fulfill obligations regarding pensions and social security contributions [4].

questions.question: For major capital procurements, the PPA requires the Procurement Planning Committee to align the project with the MDA's needs assessment and the strategic objectives outlined in the:
questions.explanation: Procurement planning must be based on approved budget which is derived from the Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF), focusing on three-year projections [40].

questions.question: Which administrative body within the MDA is responsible for reviewing and endorsing the Procurement Plan before it is submitted for final approval?
questions.explanation: The Ministerial Tenders Board (MTB) reviews and endorses the Procurement Plan before submission to the next approval level.

questions.question: The PPA principle of *fair competition* is particularly critical in the selection of consultants to ensure that selection is based on:
options: The number of social media followers.
Objective technical criteria, not personal connections.
The size of the mobilization fee requested.
questions.explanation: Fair competition ensures the selection process adheres to objective, technical criteria (QCBS), promoting Section 16 principles.

questions.question: Under what condition can an MDA legally pay a consultant using an Advance Payment Guarantee (APG) or Performance Bond?
options: Never, consultants receive payment in full upfront.
When the Accounting Officer personally approves it.
To secure the mobilization fee (advance payment) of up to 30%.
If the consultant is a foreign firm.
questions.explanation: Advance payments (mobilization fee, max 30%) require the contractor/consultant to provide an APG or Performance Bond to secure the government funds [41, 42].

questions.question: The use of the **Vote Book** (FR 601) in procurement budgeting primarily supports which internal control mechanism?
questions.explanation: The Vote Book is the mechanism for Obligation Control, preventing the MDA from exceeding its financial limits [43-45].

questions.question: Which of the following documents is required by the PPA to verify a bidderâ€™s eligibility regarding their employment history and workforce integrity?
questions.explanation: Eligibility requires evidence of compliance with pension obligations, confirmed by a Pension Clearance Certificate (Section 16) [4].

questions.question: If a consulting contract is found to contain gross irregularities, the BPP is empowered to suspend or cancel the proceedings under which section?
questions.explanation: Section 53 empowers the BPP to suspend or cancel proceedings if irregularities are detected, ensuring due process [46, 47].

questions.question: The PPA mandates that the procurement planning process must precede the tendering phase, ensuring that the necessary funds have been secured through:
questions.explanation: All procurement must be initiated based on funds appropriated by the National Assembly via the Appropriation Act (Section 14) [13, 48].

questions.question: The use of **Quality-Based Selection (QBS)** for consulting services is justified when:
options: The cost is the most important factor.
The assignment is complex and highly specialized, and quality is paramount.
The project is below â‚¦1 million.
The consultant is related to the Accounting Officer.
questions.explanation: QBS is used for highly complex assignments where the outcome quality far outweighs the cost consideration (Section 43 implied).

questions.question: An officer involved in procurement who fails to disclose a close relationship with a bidding firm violates the prohibition against:
questions.explanation: Failure to disclose such a relationship violates the ethical mandate against conflict of interest (Section 57 PPA) [49-51].

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an eligibility requirement that the BPP maintains a database on (Section 9)?
questions.explanation: The BPP database (Section 9) records performance, classification, and eligibility, but not private details like religious affiliation [52].

questions.question: If an MDA's Procurement Plan requires a major Virement (change of budget allocation) for a project, the MDA must seek approval from:
options: The appropriate authority designated to approve that level of expenditure (e.g., NASS).
questions.explanation: Major virement requests, especially if affecting approved programs, require legislative or FEC approval to maintain budget fidelity [53].

subcategories.name: Implementation, Monitoring & Sanctions
subcategories.description: Contract implementation, performance monitoring, sanctions for contractors and officers, and dispute resolution.

questions.question: Which section of the PPA 2007 requires procuring entities to monitor contract performance to ensure compliance with terms and specifications?
questions.explanation: Section 35 provides guidelines for proper contract implementation and monitoring by procuring entities to ensure compliance with terms and specifications [1, 2].

questions.question: The PPA mandates that contracts must be executed efficiently and in good faith, which is emphasized in:
questions.explanation: Section 35 emphasizes efficient and good faith implementation of contracts [2].

questions.question: What is the consequence for a contractor who fails to provide the required Performance Bond (Section 29) after contract award?
options: The contract variation must be approved by FEC.
The project is transferred to another MDA.
questions.explanation: Failure to submit the mandated Performance Bond (Section 29) to secure government payment typically leads to contract termination, as the government is exposed to risk [3].

questions.question: What document must be issued to confirm satisfactory delivery of goods or services before the final payment is processed to the contractor?
questions.explanation: No payment is processed without the Job Completion Certificate (JCC), confirming that work was done or goods were received satisfactorily [4, 5].

questions.question: Procurement documents and records must be retained by the procuring entity for audit and inspection purposes for a minimum period of:
questions.explanation: Section 38 requires that all procurement documents be retained for a minimum of 5 years to facilitate audit and inspection [6].

questions.question: If a loss of government funds or property is discovered, which three offices (among others) must be notified promptly for proper investigation and accountability?
options: Permanent Secretary, Legal Department, and Budget Office
questions.explanation: Mandatory loss reporting requires notification to the Police, Accountant-General, and Auditor-General for criminal and fiscal accountability [7, 8].

questions.question: The statutory power to conduct procurement audits of MDAs to monitor compliance is vested in which body?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF).
questions.explanation: Section 6 of the PPA 2007 empowers the BPP to conduct mandatory procurement audits of procuring entities [9].

questions.question: The mandatory sanction for a contractor found guilty of fraud, corruption, or collusion (Section 58) is:
options: Blacklisting (Exclusion from all future federal tenders).
questions.explanation: Section 58(6) empowers the BPP to blacklist contractors, disqualifying them permanently from future federal tenders [10, 11].

questions.question: Which specific penalty is imposed on an officer to recover the exact amount of financial loss caused by their negligence or misconduct?
questions.explanation: Surcharge is the recovery of government losses from the officer's pay, applied when the loss is due to the officerâ€™s fault [12].

questions.question: Section 57 strictly prohibits public officials involved in procurement from having any personal interest that might compromise their judgment. This is the rule against:
questions.explanation: Section 57 strictly prohibits conflict of interest in procurement proceedings and mandates disclosure [13].

questions.question: Contract implementation reports (Contract Execution Reports) are essential during the monitoring phase for:
options: Tracking physical and financial progress on capital projects.
questions.explanation: Project Monitoring Reports track physical and financial progress on capital projects [13, 14].

questions.question: The disbursement of a mobilization fee (advance payment) to a contractor requires them to first provide:
options: An Advance Payment Guarantee (APG) or Performance Bond.
questions.explanation: Mobilization fees are paid subject to the contractor providing a Performance Bond or APG (Section 35/FR) to secure the funds [3, 15, 16].

questions.question: Which official publication must be used to publish all contract awards above the required threshold, supporting the principle of transparency?
options: The National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Circulars.
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires the publication of contract awards above thresholds in the Procurement Journal [15, 17].

questions.question: If the BPP detects irregularities in a procurement proceeding, it is empowered by Section 53 to take which action before the contract is formally awarded?
options: Suspend or cancel the procurement proceedings.
Release all funds to the MDA.
questions.explanation: Section 53 empowers the BPP to suspend or cancel procurement proceedings if irregularities are detected, enforcing due process [11].

questions.question: An officer under **Interdiction** (temporary suspension pending investigation) receives which payment status, according to the PSR?
questions.explanation: During interdiction, an officer is temporarily removed from duty with half pay pending the outcome of the investigation (Rule 020412/100404) [18-20].

questions.question: Falsification of official records or documents by a civil servant constitutes which disciplinary category under the PSR?
questions.explanation: Falsification of official records is explicitly listed as Serious Misconduct (Rule 100401), warranting dismissal [21, 22].

questions.question: The BPPâ€™s maintenance of a national database of contractors (Section 9) supports monitoring by providing verified information on the contractorâ€™s:
questions.explanation: The BPP database monitors contractor performance and eligibility, supporting sanctions like blacklisting [6, 11].

questions.question: Which administrative body is responsible for managing the resolution of procurement complaints filed by aggrieved bidders?
questions.explanation: The Procurement Complaint Review Committee handles administrative dispute resolution before legal litigation [23].

questions.question: An officer aggrieved by a disciplinary decision (e.g., reduction in rank) must appeal to the appropriate authority within how many days of the decision being communicated?
questions.explanation: An officer who wishes to appeal a disciplinary decision must do so within 30 days of the decision being communicated [24, 25].

questions.question: Contract Variation (adjustment to price or terms) is permitted under the PPA only with proper justification and adherence to:
options: Strict legal margin and approval procedures.
questions.explanation: Contract variation (Section 35(2)) is permitted only with valid justification and must follow due approval procedures within the legal margin [14, 17].

questions.question: Who gives the final ratification to amendments and revisions of the Public Service Rules (PSR), ensuring their binding effect across the Federation?
options: The Office of the Head of Civil Service (OHCSF).
questions.explanation: The Federal Executive Council (FEC) gives the final approval and ratification to revised PSR amendments [26-28].

questions.question: When an Internal Auditor raises an **Audit Alarm** due to a suspected irregularity in a financial transaction, the required administrative action is:
options: A detailed investigation into the irregularity.
A salary increase for the Internal Auditor.
questions.explanation: An Audit Alarm necessitates a detailed investigation into the suspected irregularity [29].

questions.question: Improper behavior, such as lateness, insubordination, or negligence, is classified under the PSR as:
questions.explanation: Misconduct (Rule 100301) covers improper behavior that undermines the image of the service [30, 31].

questions.question: The ultimate disciplinary penalty for Serious Misconduct that results in the loss of all claims to retirement benefits is:
questions.explanation: Dismissal is the ultimate penalty for serious misconduct (Rule 100401), resulting in permanent removal and forfeiture of most benefits [31-33].

questions.question: The separation of rolesâ€”where different officers handle approval, custody, and recording of financial transactionsâ€”is a key internal control known as:
questions.explanation: Segregation of Duties is the first line of defense against financial fraud [34, 35].

questions.question: Grave offenses such as corruption, fraud, unauthorized disclosure, or criminal convictions are categorized under the PSR as:
questions.explanation: Serious Misconduct (Rule 100401) covers grave offenses incompatible with public service ethics [22, 31].

questions.question: An officer who is absent from duty without leave for 14 consecutive days may be deemed by the Service to have:
questions.explanation: Rule 030413 states that unauthorized absence for 14 consecutive days is construed as resignation from the service [36, 37].

questions.question: The final certification needed to confirm physical completion of a contract or delivery of goods is the:
questions.explanation: The Job Completion Certificate (JCC) confirms satisfactory delivery of goods or completion of work before payment authorization [4, 5].

questions.question: The final authority responsible for the appointment, promotion, and discipline of Directors (GL 17) in the Federal Civil Service is the:
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF).
questions.explanation: The FCSC is vested with powers to appoint, promote, and discipline civil servants up to certain grade levels, including the Directorate Cadre [38].

questions.question: The mechanism that documents the flow of financial transactions chronologically to ensure integrity and traceability is known as the:
questions.explanation: The Audit Trail documents the flow of transactions, allowing auditors to verify integrity and traceability, ensuring accountability and transparency [4, 39].

questions.question: Section 35 requires that contract monitoring should verify compliance with contract terms, timeliness, and which overarching principle?
questions.explanation: Section 35 emphasizes efficient and good faith implementation of contracts [1, 2].

questions.question: The final authority on matters of ethical conduct and compliance with the PSR, particularly concerning disciplinary appeals, rests with the:
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.
questions.explanation: The Civil Service Commission has ultimate authority on matters of ethical conduct and appeals [40, 41].

questions.question: The offense of bid rigging, collusion, or conspiracy to restrict competition is explicitly prohibited by which section of the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes penalties for fraudulent practices, including conspiracy to rig bids and collusion [42].

questions.question: The prohibition on **Contract Splitting** (Section 58(4)) is an accountability measure designed to prevent circumvention of:
questions.explanation: Contract splitting is prohibited under Section 58(4) because it is used to evade appropriate approval limits [42].

questions.question: What document serves as the formal authorization for the release of funds from the Treasury to the MDAs for execution of budgeted projects?
questions.explanation: A Warrant provides the authority for the release of funds for both capital and recurrent expenditures [43, 44].

questions.question: If an officer resigns during a training bond period, the consequence typically involves:
options: Forfeiture of the bond amount only.
Repayment of training costs and/or additional service.
questions.explanation: Resignation during a bond period may require repayment of training costs and/or additional service [45].
